message.content: This question involves understanding the behavior of light when it interacts with reflective objects. When light hits a reflective object, it is redirected or reflected off the object's surface. This is the basic principle behind how mirrors work. Option (A) is incorrect because if light never reaches the object, it wouldn't be able to reflect off it. Option (B) is incorrect because light illuminates the front side of the object, not the backside. Option (C) is incorrect because light does not usually go above the object unless there is a specific angle or surface that causes it to do so.

This question tests knowledge about the behavior of light when it hits a reflective object. When light hits a reflective object, it is redirected or reflected off the surface of the object. This is known as the law of reflection. Option (A) is incorrect because if the light never reached the object, it would not be reflective. Option (B) is incorrect because the light does not illuminate the backside of the object, it is reflected off the front surface. Option (C) is incorrect because the light does not go above the object, it hits the surface and is reflected.

This question requires basic knowledge about how light behaves when it hits a reflective object. When light hits a reflective object, it is redirected or reflected off the surface of the object. Option (A) is incorrect because if light never reaches the object, it wouldn't be able to reflect off it. Option (B) is incorrect because light does not illuminate the backside of the object, it reflects off the front side. Option (C) is incorrect because light does not go above the object, it reflects off the surface.

This question requires basic knowledge about the behavior of light. When light hits a reflective object, it is redirected or reflected from the object. This is because reflective objects have a smooth surface that allows the light to bounce off it. Option (A) is incorrect because if the light never reached the object, it wouldn't be able to reflect from it. Option (B) is incorrect because the backside of the object may not be illuminated depending on the angle of the light. Option (C) is incorrect because the light does not go above the object unless there is a specific reflective surface or angle that allows for such behavior.

This question requires basic knowledge about the behavior of light. When light hits a reflective object, it is redirected from it. This is because the reflective surface bounces the light off at the same angle at which it hit the surface, following the law of reflection. Option (A) is incorrect because if the light never reached the object, it would not be able to reflect off it. Option (B) is incorrect because light illuminates the front side of the object, not the backside. Option (C) is incorrect because light does not go above the object unless there is another reflective surface above it.

This question requires basic knowledge about the behavior of light when it interacts with reflective objects. When light hits a reflective object, it is redirected or reflected from it. This is why we can see objects in our surroundings - because light bounces off of them and reaches our eyes. Option (A) is incorrect because if light never reached reflective objects, we would not be able to see them. Option (B) is incorrect because the backside of the object is not necessarily illuminated when light hits it. Option (C) is incorrect because light does not go above reflective objects, but rather reflects off of them.
